Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dry ice floods into the large open space. By upper railings stand people in white uniforms with Prussian style hats \- the ones with a nasty spike sticking out of the top. Another waits downstairs. A woman, also in white, leads in six people. Everyone say Hi! to  Patricia Quinn aka Magenta from the Rocky Horror Picture Show.

Dialogue.Line: Halt!
Oh, you lucky, lucky people. You are the chosen ones, the elite, specially selected to join our force of mercenaries and create fear and terror wherever you go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone say Hi! to  Tony Osoba, back again after eight years.

Dialogue.Line: We were tricked.
Kane has paid seventeen crowns for each of you, and he insists on value for money.
Seventeen crowns? You couldn't even buy a dog for seventeen crowns.
Precisely. I wouldn't have paid seventeen crowns for the lot of you, let alone each.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kracauer pushes him back and he falls, touching one of the boxes giving out the dry ice. It burns.

Dialogue.Line: Only frostburn.
Frostburn?
Liquid nitrogen. Minus two hundred Celsius. Just be thankful your arm didn't go inside the vat, otherwise it would never have come out again. Right, freeze them.
Wait! You mean we're going to be frozen?
Until Kane needs your services, yes. What's the matter, getting cold feet?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs moves the other men out. Zed hits the remaining guard, takes his weapon and tries to run for it. Kracauer starts shooting.

Dialogue.Line: Kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zed runs through a door.

Dialogue.Line: Leave him. He's in the restricted zone. He's a dead man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zed has gone into a room where an old man is chiseling at a huge slab of ice. He trips and drops his newly acquired weapon into a vat. A white clad arm with gold braid reaches in and takes it out, handing it back. Zed drops it on the floor, where it shatters, then the pale faced man puts his hands on ??'s face, and he dies.

Dialogue.Line: Pay no attention to the intruder. You may continue with your work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows small planetoid sunlit at the bottom and with a massive city on the opposite side.

Dialogue.Line: Where is it?

Iceworld. A space trading colony on the dark side of the planet Svartos. Space travellers stop there for supplies. I've been picking up a faint tracking signal for some time. I think there's something interesting going on there, Mel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A woman looks in a chest freezer then drags her daughter away. The tannoy makes an announcement.

Dialogue.Line: Don't miss our special offer in the nurturing spares department. Photon refrigeration units for only twenty four ninety five. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises. Only the little girl looks up as Mel and the Doctor come out.

Dialogue.Line: A freezer centre? How boring.
Oh, trust not appearances, Mel. You never know what might be lurking in the freezer chests. Think gothic.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girl runs up to Mel wearing a mask, making her gasp then smile.

Dialogue.Line: This way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Amongst the people at the tables of this down market Cantina is Sabalom Glitz, who is complaining about something to a well built teenaged waitress. Everyone say Hi! to  Sophie Aldred.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, two of your best strawberry milkshakes, if you please.
Certainly, sir.
There must be some mistake in the reckoning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Mel sit at the next table, and he takes out a book to read. The Doctor's Dilemma, by Bernard Shaw.

Dialogue.Line: The mistake's in your wallet, not my arithmetic.
Do you take Asteroid Express?
Glitz!
Glitz!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes the credit card and goes to the bar as the Doctor and Mel join Glitz at his table.

Dialogue.Line: What? No, never heard of him.
It's us, Mel and the Doctor. You haven't forgotten us, have you, Glitz?
Shush. Keep your voice down. No, of course I haven't forgotten you. Mel, and the Doc. Here, you're not the Doctor.
I've regenerated. The difference is purely perceptual.
Here, you couldn't do us a favour, could you? You see, I'm in a spot of bother.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace brings the Doctor and Mel's drinks.

Dialogue.Line: What's this, Glitz? Not another one of your dodgy deals backfired?
No, no, nothing like that, straight up. Fact is, I'm on a mission of highly philanthropic nature.
What's that?
It means it's beneficial to mankind.
We know what philanthropic means. What's the mission?
I have been entrusted to deliver certain secret documents which nefarious unnamed parties would stop at nothing to grasp within their own grubby digits.
You mean
They'd kill you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three of Kane's white clad mercenaries. Belazs touches Glitz' shoulder.

Dialogue.Line: Sabalom Glitz, we've been looking for you.
Leave him alone. If you kill him, you kill us too.
Er, steady on there, Mel.
What are you talking about?
Oh, he's told us everything, about how you tried to stop him delivering secret documents
Shush.
Becoming quite a story-teller, aren't we, Glitz? I'm afraid you also seem to be a victim of Mister Glitz's cavalier attitude toward facts.
Glitz.
I'm not interested in any secret documents which Mister Glitz may or may not possess. I am more concerned with the hundred crowns he took from my employer, Mister Kane, under false pretences.
That was highest quality merchandise.
A space freighter full of deep frozen fruit which turned out to be rotten.
Oh, a bit on the ripe side, maybe.
They were putrefying, Glitz.
A little past their prime, perhaps.
And Mister Kane does not run Iceworld to subsidise crooks like yourself. The hundred crowns, please.
I think you'd better pay back the money, Glitz.
I can't.
Why not?
Well, you see, there was this game of cards. I got well damaged.
What about the hundred and two crowns you sold your crew for?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to his book.

Dialogue.Line: Sold your crew?
Well, the mutinous rabble, they tried to take command of my spacecraft. I relieved myself of them for seventeen crowns a piece. Rather more than they were worth, I think.
The money.
Gone the way of all organic matter, I'm afraid. Down the tube.
In that case, we're confiscating your spacecraft.
The Nosferatu? You can't do that.
You have seventy two hours to find one hundred crowns or you lose your spacecraft.
But it's my livelihood.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs and the two mercenaries leave.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, you've got to help me.
You've only got yourself to blame.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The remaining members of Glitz's crew go into freezer alcoves.

Dialogue.Line: We're going to have trouble with this lot when you defrost them, Mister Kane.
Trouble?
They didn't volunteer willingly.

None of my mercenary force will be willing when I bring them out of cryosleep. The process causes complete loss of memory. With no memories they can have no past, no future, no will of their own, no purpose except to obey me. Through them I shall be invincible. My power shall be absolute.
You will do as you're told. Less of your lip or you're out on your ear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace delivers a drink to a customer then goes to Mel and the Doctor. Glitz is listening in from his table.

Dialogue.Line: Hope the dragon gets you in the night.
Dragon? What dragon?
It's just a legend. There's supposed to be a terrifying dragon living in the ice passages underneath Iceworld.
I knew there must be a reason why you brought us here. You want to see the dragon, don't you.
Oh really, Mel, it's fascinating. Travellers claim to have seen it throughout the centuries but there's never been any proof.
Like the Lock Ness monster.
Loch.
Och!
You're going to go looking for the dragon?
Absolutely.
Oh, cool. Can I come too?
Won't you get into trouble with your boss?
Oh, I'm fed up with being a waitress. Oh, go on, Professor, let me come too.
Well, I don't see why not.
Ace! And can we search for the treasure, too?
Treasure?
Yeah. The dragon's supposed to be guarding a fabulous treasure.
(laughs) Treasure? What treasure? You don't want to go believing in myths and legends, Doctor.
Who asked you? We're not talking to you.
No, if you want my opinion, all this talk of treasure and dragons, it's all a load of old spacedust.
Well, if you're so convinced it's all rubbish, why have you been burning holes in this treasure map for the last two days?
He says he lost the money in a game of cards.
I know he lost the money in a game of cards. The game was fixed. What about the map?
He's convinced it's genuine.
Excellent. He'll soon realise if he wants to see his spacecraft again he has no alternative but to go after the treasure. And when he does, I shall be with him every step of the way.
There's just one thing.
Yes?
He appears to have two colleagues.
Colleagues? I thought he sold his entire crew.
They're not from his crew, sir. Space travellers. A man and a girl. Do you want them eliminated?
Not for the moment, I think. There's no reason for them to suspect that the seal on the treasure map contains a tracking device.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is studying the map.

Dialogue.Line: Fascinating. Absolutely fascinating.
Looks like something from a jumble sale to me.
Oi, there's nothing snide about this document.
You don't want to believe nothing you get from him, Professor. He probably bought two hundred of them in a job lot.
Do you mind? This is the real McCoy, this is. It comes from an unimpeachable source.
What's that, then?
That means it is beyond reproach or question.
I know what unimpeachable means, bird bath, but what makes you so certain this map's pedigree is twenty four carat?
Because I acquired it from a man of character and distinction.
How?
I won it in er, a chess match.
You won it playing cards. Doctor, it's a waste of time. He won it in a card game.
An honest transaction. The man was desperate not to lose this map, so I know it's something very, very tasty.
It shows the lower levels of Iceworld.
No one goes down there any more. Too dangerous.
The Ice Garden, the Singing Trees.
But like the girl says, Doctor, it's too dangerous.
Where's your sense of adventure, Glitz?
What, do you want to go here, the Lake of Oblivion?
Where?
Depth of Eternal Darkness? Dragonfire? I should stop at home, if I were you.
Cor, this sounds brill.
My sentiments precisely. What's your name, incidentally?
Everyone calls me Ace.
Oh, how do you do. I'm the Doctor and this is my friend Mel.
And we're really going to go looking for dragons?
Too risky if you ask me.
Nonsense, Glitz. Time for a quick adventure then back for tea.
Ace!
That's the spirit, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor folds up the map.

Dialogue.Line: Hang about! You can't go without me, that's my map. And I don't want these girls coming along, either.
What?
It's too dangerous.
Professor!
And since it's my map
Right, you male chauvinist bilge bag, just you wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, nice.
And I was so looking forward to meeting a dragon.
Oh, it's all right, Doctor, you go on ahead. I'll wait here. And if Glitz burns his fingers in the dragon's fire, then it serves him right.
It's just you and me, then, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stops to tickle a hairy child under the chin. It barks and snarls at him.

Dialogue.Line: They have left the upper levels now.
Only two of them, you say?
Glitz and the traveller called the Doctor. They're just setting off for the lower levels.
Excellent. Continue to monitor the tracking device. Well?
It's Glitz's spacecraft.
What of it?
It's just that
Yes?
Well, if Glitz and the Doctor are as good as dead, I'd like the spacecraft.

Oh, you'd like the spacecraft, would you? When you first came here you had nothing. You were willing enough to take my payment then. But now you want to leave. Perhaps you have memories of a home you can return to? Perhaps I should have put you into cryosleep along with all the others and erased your memories.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kane takes Belazs' face with one hand and holds up his ungloved hand to it. She flinches and he takes her left hand instead.

Dialogue.Line: Perhaps you need reminding. As long as you bear my mark, I own you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Her palm has the imprint of a coin burnt into it. Kane activates the communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, sir?
Glitz's spacecraft. Have it destroyed.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes drinks to the woman and her daughter, then unpins her bun to release a pony tail.

Dialogue.Line: Would the emergency services please report to the docking bay to deal with an ice jam. Thank you.
It's all your fault.
How'd you work that out?
You were encouraging them both. Oh ace, oh brill.
You girl. Yes, you, girl. Come here.
What do you want?
This milkshake isn't adequately shaken.
That's how they come, missus.
It's got lumps in it.
It's supposed to have lumps in it. That's the ice cream.
But we don't want lumps in it. Shake it some more.
Shake it yourself.
I beg your pardon?
You heard.
I've never been so insulted
Bet you've never had a milk shake tipped over your head, neither.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace is as good as her word. The woman squeals and the barman cum manager rushes to her.

Dialogue.Line: I'm awfully sorry, madam. That does it, you're fired.
I'm sorry. It won't happen again.
Get out. I've had enough of you.
I promise it'll never happen again.
Get out! You too, out.
Me?
Both of you. Out!
All right, I'm going.
You're troublemakers, hooligans. I do apologise for my staff. I do assure you, those milk shakes don't stain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace's last act is to tip one over his head, too.
The image of a woman is being cut from the ice block. Kane admires it then goes to lie on a table.

Dialogue.Line: Current ambient temperature minus ten Celsius. Target temperature minus a hundred and ninety three Celsius.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A clear lid closes over Kane.

Dialogue.Line: Cabinet temperature dropping.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A typical teenage mess.

Dialogue.Line: If there's anyone in the emergency control room, would you please answer the phone. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace and Mel enter. Ace throws herself on the bed.

Dialogue.Line: Well, come on in, if you're going to. He really gets up my nostrils, that Glitz.
Oh, he's all right underneath.
No. He's a grade A hundred percent div, that's what he is. Underneath.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel starts picking up clothes in the hunt for a chair to sit on.

Dialogue.Line: Look, leave those alone, will you?
I was only trying to make room to sit.
Well, just sit on top of them like everyone else does, can't you?
All right, all right.
I've been meaning to do the washing for a couple of weeks.
Looks more like a couple of months to me.
You're just like the teachers used to be at school. How do you expect to pass your chemistry A level if you can't even store the equipment properly?
A level? You're from Earth?
Used to be.
Whereabouts on Earth?
Perivale.
Sounds nice.
You ever been there?
No.
I was doing this brill experiment to extract nitroglycerine from gelignite, but I think something must have gone wrong. This time storm blows up from nowhere and whisks me up here.
When was this?
Does it matter?
Well, don't you ever want to go back?
Not particularly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace changes out of her waitress apron and puts on a padded jacket decorated with NASA space mission badges. And a Fanderson one, and Ace Roofing Co.

Dialogue.Line: What about your mum and dad?
I haven't got no mum and dad. I've never had no mum and dad and I don't want no mum and dad. It's just me, all right?
Sorry. What about your chemistry A level, then?
That's no good. I got suspended after I blew up the art room.
You blew up the art room?
It was only a small explosion. They couldn't understand how blowing up the art room was a creative act.
If anyone sees any member of the emergency services, will you please ask them to pop along to the upper docking bay when they've a moment to spare. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes some pressurised cans from a rucksack.

Dialogue.Line: Isn't anyone going to do anything about that ice jam blocking the docking bay? Here, take these.
Deodorant?
They're just old cans. They've got home made Nitro Nine in them now.
Nitro Nine?
It's just like ordinary nitroglycerine, except it's got a bit more wallop. Careful you don't drop them. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace puts the rucksack over her shoulder and leaves.
Belazs watches Kane in the restricted zone through a glass door.

Dialogue.Line: Cabinet at minus a hundred and ninety three Celsius.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She goes to the central console and activates the communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, sir.
It's me, Belazs. (pronounced Belaj) Mister Kane has changed his mind about Glitz's spacecraft. It's not to be destroyed, do you understand?
Spacecraft is not to be destroyed.
That is correct.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Glitz are following the map along catwalks between walls of ice. They stop at an intersection.

Dialogue.Line: Have you seen any Singing Trees or Ice Gardens, Glitz?
We're still too close to the upper levels, Doctor. Let's cast me eyes over the map.
Well, since we've come from that direction, I think we should go in that direction. Then again

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz drops the map and bends to retrieve it as the Doctor's umbrella swings above his head.

Dialogue.Line: Perhaps that direction. Yes. And keep your eyes peeled for any Singing Trees or Ice Gardens, Glitz.
Come on, both sides, push! Harder! Push.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel and Ace enter.

Dialogue.Line: Gordon Bennett, what a bunch of Spocks. They'll never get it open at that rate. Here, let's have a couple of those.
You're not going to use those, are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace pulls the tops of the cans and walks up to the frozen hatchway.

Dialogue.Line: If I were you lot, I'd go for your tea break now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She sticks the cans on the ice.

Dialogue.Line: Why? What's in those cans?
Nitro Nine. We've got eight seconds. Last one back's a gooey mess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace and Mel run.

Dialogue.Line: Nitro? Everybody, get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bang!

Dialogue.Line: Ace!
Ace!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs enters and goes over to the temperature monitor, then back to the sculpture.

Dialogue.Line: Target blood temperature of minus one hundred and ninety three Celsius achieved.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kane gets out of his cabinet.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing in the restricted zone?
I was looking for you. There's been an ice jam in the upper docking bay and the emergency services haven't responded.
Must I do everything myself? Go there immediately and take charge of the situation.
Of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An area of stalactites, crystalline stalagmites and a tinkling sound.

Dialogue.Line: Singing Trees.
But these aren't trees.
Use your imagination, Glitz. Willow trees, something like that.
Well, where's the singing coming from?
Air current causes the crystal membranes to vibrate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz picks up an icicle.

Dialogue.Line: I bet this is worth a few grotzits.
Yes, what's it do?
Do?
Yes. Some sort of opto-electronic circuit. But why? I mean, what's it doing here?
You mean someone made all this? Dragons?
Possibly. Come on, Glitz. Tempus fugit. I want to be back in time for tea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs enters with an escort.

Dialogue.Line: What is going on? You two are under arrest. Take them away.
What?
Hang about! Put me down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel and Ace are hustled away.

Dialogue.Line: Leave me alone! Get off! Stop it! Not fair!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz takes a right turn by a formation that looks like flowers, leaving the Doctor alone on the slippery passageway.

Dialogue.Line: Glitz? Glitz? Glitz?
Quite a little expert with explosives, I hear.
Yeah? So what if I am.
Excellent. I like women with fire in their bellies, don't I, Belazs? I might yet have a use for you.
Oh yeah? What makes you think I'd be interested?
Oh, I can be very persuasive.
I'm not frightened of you.
Good. Because I shall need people like you in my army of mercenaries.
You what?
Think about it. Travelling through the twelve galaxies, the diamond sparkle of meteorite showers, the rainbow flashes of an ion storm. Think about it.
Don't listen to him, Ace!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace snaps out of her trance.

Dialogue.Line: How old are you?
Six... eighteen.
Eighteen, eh? No home to call your own. The twelve galaxies are your home. Come with me. I understand you.
It won't be like that, Ace! Don't believe him.
Join me. Take my golden sovereign.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts it on the console for her. Its intense cold steams against the metal.

Dialogue.Line: Take the sovereign.
Don't do it, Ace! Please, don't do it!
You've heard altogether too much. Freeze her!
No, Ace!
Take my coin. Take the coin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace knocks the coin to the floor and brandishes a can of Nitro Nine.

Dialogue.Line: Right, freeze! I mean, don't freeze. Stand still and let Mel go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kane nods.

Dialogue.Line: You stupid girl. Think it's that easy to walk away from me?
Do you feel like arguing with a can of deodorant that registers nine on the Richter scale? Run!
Wicked!
Get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel pulls Ace back before it fires something that sparks when it hits the icewall.

Dialogue.Line: That's not a real dragon. That was a laser beam.
Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz is looking over the railing at the Doctor dangling from his umbrella.

Dialogue.Line: It's no use, Doctor. I've located the Ice Garden but there's a distinct absence of dragon or treasure.
Glitz, I sympathise with your disappointment, but I'm about to plummet to my death.
Oh, I suppose you want me to risk my neck and come and help you.
Glitz!
All right, all right. Don't get your delicates in a twist.
Glitz!

Belazs, you astound me. Those two girls should have been searched when they were arrested. You seem to be taking advantage of my former feelings for you. Be warned, the past is an empty slate. I demand absolute loyalty now and forever, and I don't forgive those who betray me. The girls must be stopped before they reach Glitz and the Doctor. They must be eradicated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kane activates the control to open up some freezer units.

Dialogue.Line: What could be more appropriate than to despatch some of Glitz's former crew after the girls. He betrayed his crew, now they can have their revenge. Everyone should be allowed his moment of revenge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor climbs down off Glitz's shoulders in the most convoluted fashion, ending upside down between his legs.

Dialogue.Line: I say, thank you.

It's no use, Doctor. Even if we did find the treasure, it'd take us longer than seventy two hours, and Belazs said if I didn't return Kane's money within seventy two hours they'd confiscate my spacecraft.
Why don't you explain the problem to him?
Oh, he'd slice his own mother up to make a point. If he was a mortician, the corpses would keep their eyes open.
Ah.
In fact, if Kane knew we were after the

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs is listening in via the tracker in the map seal.

Dialogue.Line: Dragon's treasure, your life expectancy wouldn't be looking too clever at the moment. He's a cold man, Doctor. Cut him open and you won't find a heart, just a lump of ice.
These types never have any sense of fair play.
Exactly. Which is why I've come to the conclusion that play it by the rules is a mug's game. I have decided to hijack the Nosferatu. Which is where you come in, Doctor.
Ah, hang on there a minute, Glitz. I'm engaged in a project of scientific curiosity. I mean, that dragon, or whatever it may turn out to be, could be an undiscovered species.
Look, I'll do you a good deal. You help me get the Nosferatu back, and I'll give you the treasure map so's you and Mel can go looking for this dragon. I can't say fairer than that, can I?
You have me there, Glitz. Without the map, I'll never find the creature.
You're a man of insight and logic, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz gives the Doctor the map.

Dialogue.Line: All right, then. Where's the Nosferatu berthed?
In the lower docking bay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The zombie crew march along the ice cat walks.
The sculptor is at work.

Dialogue.Line: A work of artistry, my friend. Incandescent artistry. I could almost believe Xana lives again. A unique beauty, yes, but more than that, a criminal genius also. Oh, what a waste. It should have been I who was killed escaping arrest, not you.
You're joking. I'm not going down there.
Look, there's the Doctor's brolly. We must be on the right track.
What did he have to come this way for? I could break my neck.
How are we going to get down there?
Hang on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace rummages in her rucksack and produces a roll of slim metal ladder.

Dialogue.Line: There's only one guard. Do you think you can occupy him while I slip on board?
I'll do my best.
Go on, then. Away you go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks up to the guard.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me. What's your attitude towards the nature of existence? For example, do you hold any strong theological opinions?
I think you'll find most educated people regard mythical convictions as fundamentally animistic.
I see. That's a very interesting concept.
Personally, I find most experiences border on the existential.
Well, how do you reconcile that with the empirical critical belief that experience is at the root of all phenomena?
I think you'll find that a concept can be philosophically valid even if theologically meaningless.
So, what you're saying is that before Plato existed, someone had to have the idea of Plato.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz slips into the docking bay.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, you've no idea what a relief it is for me to have such a stimulating philosophical discussion. There are so few intellectuals about these days. Tell me, what do you think of the assertion that the semiotic thickness of a performed text varies according to the redundancy of auxiliary performance codes?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel starts down the ladder, collecting the Doctor's umbrella on the way. Ace follows.
Small, messy with a pair of giant fluffy dice dangling from a chain.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, my ship. Soon be light years away from this place.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Glitz straps himself into the pilots seat then gets a gun placed to his head.

Dialogue.Line: I wouldn't touch those controls if I were you.
Wicked. And the bilge bag said this was too dangerous for girls.
This spacecraft is mine.
Hang on, the seventy two hours aren't up yet. You said if I could get hold of the grotzits I could have the Nosferatu back.
Then I shall just have to make sure you don't manage to find the money in time. I shall have to make very sure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs in.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. Not interrupting anything, am I?
What are you doing here?
That's a very difficult question. Why is everyone round here so preoccupied with metaphysics?
I think she's going to kill us, Doctor.
Ah. An existentialist.
Quiet! Only one of us can leave Iceworld aboard the Nosferatu, and one way or the other it's going to be me.
What about the boss, Mister Kane? Does he know of your little enterprise?
Kane doesn't own me.
Oh, I think he does. I think he bought you like he buys everything in Iceworld.
What would you know about it?
I think he bought you a long time ago. He paid seventeen crowns for each of Glitz's crew. How much did he pay for you? Was it worth it? Were you worth it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Belazs holds up her burnt palm.

Dialogue.Line: That's what I sold myself for, Kane's mark. I ought to cut my hand off for doing it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Belazs is distracted by the Doctor, Glitz unbuckles himself and takes her gun.

Dialogue.Line: Go on, then. Kill me!
Well, come on, Doctor. We've got the Nosferatu back. Let's get out of here.

No, Glitz. You can't go on stealing everything you want, like this Stradivarius and that Dutch master. Pay Kane back his debt, even if it costs a thousand crowns, ten thousand crowns. Pay back the debt. And as for you, your debt to Kane, I don't think you'll be able to pay it off. Ever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The statue is completed.

Dialogue.Line: The whole of eternity has held its breath for this moment. But no one must ever see your work. It exists, that is enough. No one can ever look upon your work and live. Gaze on it and die fulfilled.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kane places his bare hands on the sculptor's face and freezes him to death.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
Shush. Did you hear that?
Hear what?
I thought I heard something.
Well, what kind of something?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The zombie crew are coming up behind them.
